Award.AwardTitle: Arizona School of Analysis and Mathematical Physics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for US participation in the conference "Arizona School of Analysis and Mathematical Physics" that will be held March 5-9, 2018 at the University of Arizona

The conference focuses on recent developments in Analysis, especially in the fields of mathematical physics and partial differential equations. A number of distinguished mathematicians have agreed to attend and speak at this conference. This award gives early career researchers, members of underrepresented groups, researchers not funded by NSF and the like an opportunity to attend and participate in this conference. The organizing committee will strive to make this funding opportunity known to target groups through a number of different activities. More information will be made available at:

http://math.arizona.edu/~mathphys/AZSchool18/

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this project was to organize a school on analysis with specific emphasis on mathematical physics. A successful researcher in mathematical physics must be familiar with a variety of tools from analysis as well as insights derived from physical intuition. For this reason, students are often overwhelmed or intimidated by the prospect of working in this area. To address this issue, we organized a school that offered four mini-courses on topics of active research in mathematical physics. These courses were designed to rigorously develop important analytic techniques, within the context of specific applications, to illustrate how theory is used in problem solving. In addition, the organizers recruited lecturers who are not only known for their impressive, international research careers, but also their history of pedagogical presentations. The mini-courses were intended to be accessible to graduate students and postdocs, self-contained, and relevant for cutting-edge, contemporary research. The school was designed to provide a forum which encouraged interactions between early-career researchers and more senior scientists. A more long-term goal was to inspire further studies and present possible avenues of future research.


Over the week of March 5-9, 2018 we organized the Arizona School of Analysis and Mathematical Physics on campus at the University of Arizona. During this week, four mini-courses were offered on important topics of current research in mathematical physics. In particular, Sven Bachmann (from the University of British Columbia) spoke on Adiabatic Dynamics and Linear Response Theory for Many-Body Quantum Systems, Gunter Stolz (from the University of Alabama at Birmingham) discussed Disordered Quantum Spin Chains, Jan Philip Solovej (from the University of Copenhagen, Denmark) explained Quasi-free Variational Models for Bosons and Fermions, and Fernando Brandao (from Caltech) lectured on Entanglement Theory. In addition, several senior participants gave invited lectures on topics related to these mini-courses. In particular, Mei Yin (from University of Denver) spoke on Ground States of Exponential Random Graphs, Bruno Nachtergaele (from the University of California at Davis) talked about Stability of the Super-selection Sectors of Kitaev's Abelian Quantum Double Models, Anna Vershynina (from University of Houston) spoke on the Data Processing Inequality and the Stability of the Recovery Map, and Jeff Schenker (from Michigan State University) discussed Localization, and Resonant Delocalization, of a Disordered Polaron.


All mini-courses and lectures from senior participants were presented and well-received. From a survey conducted after the conclusion of the school, all participants rated the program as ``very good'' or ``excellent.'' One participant commented ``The content of the lectures was an informative introduction to some methods in math physics which would be difficult to learn otherwise.'' In addition, one of our main objectives of this school was to provide a forum for early-career scientists to interact with more senior scientists. To achieve this objective, we gave all junior participants an opportunity to speak on their research interests and recent results. Specifically, 20 of 44 junior participants (45%) gave short research talks during the school. Finally, we have organized a proceedings that will be published as a special edition in Contemporary Mathematics. This edition will consist of lecture notes from two of the mini-courses, as well as survey and research articles on topics discussed during or related to the school.


In conclusion, the school exposed PhD students and postdoctoral researchers to cutting edge techniques in a variety of topics in mathematical physics. Interesting open research questions were discussed which could be investigated by PhD students as the basis of their dissertation or postdocs as new avenues of research. The participants of the Arizona School were comprised of a diverse group of young researchers. Of the 54 total participants, 11 came from underrepresented groups including 8 women and 3 Hispanic individuals. Our support of these participants has helped to advance the careers of underrepresented groups in the mathematical sciences. In particular, we provided the participants with the opportunity to share their recent results through short research talks. This gave the junior participants a platform to practice giving research talks and also facilitated conversations between participants with shared research interests. As a result, participants were able to make new research connections with other junior researchers as well as more senior members of the research community.
